Situation1: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A couple has made an initial inquiry about his availability for a wedding over a year away.
Story: The phone pressed against my ear, I listened as Mr. Goldstein’s voice rose, thick with suspicion. “How do I know this isn’t a scam? I’ve been with your company for years!” My script as a telemarketer urged me to stay calm, to answer every objection, to keep him on the line. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “Don’t let them go until you’ve addressed every concern.” I took a breath, ready to reassure him, when my other phone buzzed—a text from Miriam, the bride-to-be. “Rabbi, can you confirm our wedding date for next June? We need to book the hall.” As a rabbi, I knew how much this meant to her, how important it was to offer guidance and certainty, to be present for these milestones. My heart twisted. I couldn’t let Mr. Goldstein feel dismissed, but I also couldn’t leave Miriam waiting, anxious about her future. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my full attention, each expecting compassion and clarity. I stared at the blinking screens, torn, the seconds stretching as I wrestled with which part of myself to answer first.
